Author: manofthestars
Content:
Note that I'm fully aware of the fact that ‚ÄúMalay‚Äù is also an umbrella term of colonial origin for the people residing in the _Malay_ Archipelago, that might have been synonymous with Austronesian; a term I would be eager to accept rather than Malay. But personally, I dislike that exact definition of the word given to us, as if that narrative appears to dismiss the diverse and distinct ethnicities and identities across the archipelago, when the general perception thought of a Malay person, you'd imagine a person of the Islamic religion and customs residing in Malaysia. Therefore if the word ‚ÄúMalay‚Äù would be the umbrella term, it would glosses over the past that there are unique and different identities across the region, ruining peoples' (especially foreigners) perception of the numerous identities in the region.

Of course, the main thing we have in common is that we used the Malay language as a trading language spoken in the coasts, as would the Javanese called it, Bahasa Ayam, the chicken language vernaculars. Using the logic that who used it is automatically Malay would mean that:
- The Balinese, a group of people thought to be special for keeping their ancestral Hindu-Buddhist beliefs among Muslims and Christians in the region, are Malays 
- The Javanese, the majority Muslim people who've still kept their Hindu-Buddhist as well as their animistic roots and traditions, syncretizing it with their unique interpretation of Islam, are also Malays. (Note that Javanese populations are likely to be more diverse regarding religious identity)
- The  Makassarese, seafaring traders, diaspora builders, political networks across the archipelago, with their own scripts (Lontara), adat law, cosmology, and identity, too should be considered Malay using that logic;
- And even somehow, the Papuan ethnics, the Melanesian people almost fully distinct from the rest of people in the archipelago, but suddenly Malay due to the use of Malay language for trades.
